headline.main: Uber Joins the Bidding for Here, Nokia’s Digital Mapping Service
headline.print_headline: Uber Joins the Bidding for a Mapping Service

docs.abstract: Uber submits $3 billion bid for Here, Nokia-owned service that is the main competitor to Google Maps, as part of its bid to expand into a logistics company; Uber currently relies heavily on Google for its livery and logistics services; heavy bidding highlights rising importance of digital mapping services as companies seek to connect their devices to the Internet.

byline.original: By MARK SCOTT and MIKE ISAAC

headline.main: Google, Dominant in Search, Tries Disruptor Role in Wireless and Broadband
headline.print_headline: Two Views of Google: Monopoly or Trust-Buster

docs.abstract: James B Stewart Common Sense column examines Google's dual identity as potential monopolist and disruptive force for competition in tech world; observes that even as European Union brings antitrust charges against company, it is also poised to enter highly-consolidated markets for wireless service and broadband in the United States, forcing competitors to improve service.

docs.abstract: Uber, along with Internet titans like Facebook, Google and Twitter, assails New York City proposal that they say would give Taxi and Limousine Commission veto power over updates to apps that arrange livery services; Uber, which operates some 16,000 cars in New York and has emerged as threat to traditional taxi industry, is widely perceived as target of rule.

headline.main: Tech Giants Urge Obama to Reject Policies That Weaken Encryption
headline.print_headline: Tech Giants Urge Obama to Reject Policies That Weaken Encryption

docs.abstract: Coalition of tech industry giants, civil liberties organizations and security experts send letter to Pres Obama warning him that proposed encryption mandate could have serious consequences; administration is weighing whether to force companies to use forms of encryption that provide 'back door' for law enforcement, but industry says same weakness could be used by foreign governments and hackers.

docs.snippet: Pressure is mounting for American tech companies, including Google, to stop using complex tax structures and pay more on their European operations....
docs.lead_paragraph: Pressure is mounting for American tech companies, including Google, to stop using complex tax structures and pay more on their European operations.

headline.main: Amazon to Stop Funneling European Sales Through Low-Tax Haven
headline.print_headline: Amazon Tax Breaks End in Europe

docs.abstract: Amazon announces broad changes to its European operations, saying it will begin paying local taxes in nations where it has large operations, rather than funneling sales through tax haven of Luxembourg; change follows growing pressure from European policy makers who want American tech companies to pay more on their operations in the European Union.

headline.main: Armed With Google and YouTube, Analysts Gauge Russia’s Presence in Ukraine

headline.main: A Murky Road Ahead for Android, Despite Market Dominance

docs.abstract: Farhad Manjoo State of The Art column; Google's Android mobile operating system is by far the world's most popular, but it is poorly monetized and faces challenges from mobile upstarts; in terms of ad revenue, Android pales in comparison to Apple's iOS mobile platform.
